full_title_en: Pain Assessment in Advanced Dementia Scale (PAINAD)
medium_description_en: Assesses pain in patients with dementia.
instructions_en: Choose the description that best fits the patient's behavior.

seo.meta_description_en: The Pain Assessment in Advanced Dementia Scale (PAINAD) assesses pain in patients with cognitive impairment.
seo.keywords_en: painad, pain assessment, dementia pain scale, dementia pain, pain in dementia, demented pain scale, pain assessment, pain geriatric, pain ICU, pain elderly

how_to_use.use_case_en:
• Patients with advanced dementia who may potentially be in pain.

  • Particularly useful in aphasic patients or those who cannot otherwise report degree of pain.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• The Pain Assessment in Advanced Dementia Scale (PAINAD) is a reliable assessment tool for dementia patients.

  • It can be used in both nonverbal and verbal patients.

  • While the tool results a continuous score between 0 and 10, there is no definitive evidence that it correlates with self-reported gradations of pain; the original study only defines 0 as “no pain” and 10 as “severe pain.” Caution should be used when titrating analgesic doses based on the score.

  • Valid in varying levels of cognitive impairment from mild to severe.

  • May also be useful in elderly patients who are reluctant to report pain, as it is more objective than self-reporting.
how_to_use.why_use_en: Assessing pain in advanced dementia is intuitively difficult; a validated scale can help.

next_steps.advice_en:
• As with pain management in general, pain should be assessed serially and medications titrated accordingly.

  • The PAINAD scale requires close and attentive observation of the patient.
next_steps.critical_actions_en: Analgesic medications should be used judiciously in dementia, in a fashion guided by the patient’s (or proxy/surrogate’s) goals of care. Always keep the “double effect” of opioids in mind.

about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
The PAINAD scale was created by Warden et al based on observation of nineteen patients in dementia care units in Veterans Administration hospitals. Each patient was scored by the principal investigator and two other raters (from a pool of six). Adequate levels of interrater reliability were found between each dyad. The PAINAD score correlated well with the Discomfort Scale-Dementia of Alzheimer Type, and there was a statistically significant decrease in score after administration of analgesics.

The PAINAD scale was validated in twenty-five elderly patients hospitalized for surgical repair of a hip fracture; twelve were cognitively impaired while thirteen were intact. The PAINAD scale was positively correlated with a self-reported scale, demonstrating concurrent validity, and scores were higher when patients were likely to experience pain than when unlikely, demonstrating discriminant validity.

The PAINAD scale was prospectively validated by Mosele et al by application to six hundred patients consecutively admitted to the acute geriatric section at Padua University (Italy). It was internally reliable, and had better concurrent validity and inter-rater reliability than a self-reported numerical rating scale.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Warden V, Hurley AC, Volicer L. Development and psychometric evaluation of the Pain Assessment in Advanced Dementia (PAINAD) scale. J Am Med Dir Assoc. 2003;4(1):9-15.

Validation.text: Hutchison RW, Tucker WF, Kim S, Gilder R. Evaluation of a behavioral assessment tool for the individual unable to self-report pain. Am J Hosp Palliat Care. 2006;23(4):328-31.
Cohen-mansfield J, Lipson S. The utility of pain assessment for analgesic use in persons with dementia. Pain. 2008;134(1-2):16-23.

Dewaters T, Faut-callahan M, Mccann JJ, et al. Comparison of self-reported pain and the PAINAD scale in hospitalized cognitively impaired and intact older adults after hip fracture surgery. Orthop Nurs. 2008;27(1):21-8.

Mosele M, Inelmen EM, Toffanello ED, et al. Psychometric properties of the pain assessment in advanced dementia scale compared to self assessment of pain in elderly patients. Dement Geriatr Cogn Disord. 2012;34(1):38-43

creator_info.about_en: Victoria Warden, RN, is a nursing research health scientist at the Geriatric Research Education Clinical Center at Edith Nourse Rogers Memorial Veterans Medical Center in Bedford, Massachusetts.
